awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Virus Assembly in Extreme Environments: A Structural and Genetic Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the structure of Sulfolobus spindle-shaped virus 1 (SSV1), a virus from volcanic hot springs.  The uniquely-shaped SSV1 thrives in acidic hot springs at above 175 ˚F (80 ˚C). Determining a high-resolution SSV1 structure will contribute to understanding how proteins interact at high temperatures. Discovering the genetic determinants of the SSV1 structure will provide insight into the stability not only SSV1, but all proteins. The research will also provide insight into virus evolution, and how life could have survived the extreme conditions present on early earth and/or on extra-terrestrial planets. The project will also provide research experiences to approximately 65 undergraduates working on SSV1 mutants.  The project will communicate science to the public in collaboration with the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry. 

This research will address three open questions regarding the structure of SSV1: How does the virus form its unique spindle-shaped structure? What is the structure of the SSV1 tail that binds to the host cell? What are the critical amino acids in the capsid proteins? To answer these questions, this research will use a combination of cutting-edge cryo-electron microscopy techniques and genetic screens and selections. The research will evaluate two competing models for the SSV1 structure and could provide a new structural paradigm for virus structure. This research will provide a strong foundation for community outreach to educate and excite the public, and inspire the next generation of researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Viruses that thrive in extreme environments, particularly acidic hot springs, often have very unusual structures.  The virus SSV1 that infects a microbe that lives at 80C (174F) and pH 3 in volcanic hot springs has a unique spindle or lemon shape. It was unknown how this shape was put together from the virus’ components.  Two models for the shape were evaluated, one of fused fullerene cones (a structures somewhat like HIV) and a spiral form.  We found that the spiral form fit the SSV1 structure best. 

 

The tail of SSV1, where it presumably attaches to the host cell, is very poorly defined.  We discovered that the SSV1 tail structure has unusual 7-fold symmetry and identified some new proteins that were not previously known to be part of the virus structure. 

 

Finally, mostly through work of many talented undergraduate researchers, we discovered that the major capsid protein of SSV1, VP1, is much more genetically flexible than expected.  This is particularly surprising since this protein is essential for the virus to function and is extremely similar in many other SSV1-like viruses.

 

All of these results provide the basis for continued research on this fascinating virus. This grant also supported 6 undergraduate researchers, 3 high school students, a graduate student and a postdoctoral fellow, the majority of them from groups otherwise underrepresented in science.  This grant was instrumental in a SSV1-based course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) that trained 38 students in research and virology over the period of the grant. Four peer-reviewed publications and multiple conference presentations were supported by this grant. Results from this research formed parts of outreach to the public through the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry.
